references.R86WIL01USGP: Williams, D.F. 1986. Mammalian species of special concern in California. Wildlife Management Division Administrative Report 86-1. California Department of Fish and Game, Sacramento. 112 pp.

habitat_description:
Southwest:
Habitat:  “not dependent upon lodgepole pine (Pinus contorta) for survival... but it inhabits forests of lodgepole pine, Jeffrey pine ..., and red fir.... It’s habitat has ca. 40% cover of vegetation, with many large boulders and some open ground..... In Nevada Co., California T. speciosus occurs on the eastern slope of the Sierra Nevada in association with Jeffrey pine, ponderosa pine, and white fir.  Shrub understory consists of sticky laurel (Ceanothus velutinus), manzanita, currant (Ribes cereum), antelope-brush (Purshia tridentata), and big sagebrush (Artemisia tridentata)” (Best et al. 1994).  In the Sierra Nevada, “lodgepole-fir and subalpine belts” (Storer and Usinger 1963).  On west slope of Sierra Nevada, “in mixed conifer, Jeffrey pine, red fir, and lodgepole pine forests” (Verner and Bos 1980).  Ingles (1965) indicates “subalpine, red fir, and lodgepole forests.”  Hall (1946) cites Johnson (MS) that in an area in California where T. speciosus and T. quadrivittatus overlap, T. speciosus does not occur in limber pine and whitebark pine, which suggests that at least here it does not occur in subalpine forest.

Elevation:  1500-3300 m (Best et al. 1994).
